text: Doing some research on the Microlending use case. Many of the 'investing' advice websites talks about microlending as a way to issue loans to "third world" and "impoverished peoples" which kind of annoyed me. Came across this article: <http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2015/01/04/372684438/if-you-shouldnt-call-it-the-third-world-what-should-you-call-it>

attachments.title: If You Shouldn't Call It The Third World, What Should You Call It?
attachments.text: There are many ways to refer to the parts of our planet where people lack decent health care, education and services like electricity and clean water. And just about every label has its problems.
attachments.fallback: NPR.org: If You Shouldn't Call It The Third World, What Should You Call It?

text: > Some people use the term "Majority World" — a reminder to those of us in the West that we are but a very small minority on the globe. According to World Bank statistics, 80 percent of humanity lives on $10 or less a day.

good stuff <@U0NQY299A> --- Speaking as a concerned LATAM citizen, a Trusted and Secure IDMS is not a nice to have in my Majority World: it is necessary~!  A Security and Identity solution at the baseline level is what will transform access to banking....reputation systems, credit scores, mobile banking, cashless transacting and ultimately less predatory lending. Today, 90% of the population in Colombia use cash (govmt wants to change this), in Venezuela they don't even have cash. Of course, LATAM is only but a fraction of the Majority World....but that near and dear to me.  As you may already know, the World Bank is actively looking at Blockchain~!

<@U0KM55L9E> I'm part of a UN conference on Digital Identity <http://id2020summit.org/> discussing these issues, and leading a design workshop after the event as a following on to the #RebootingWebOfTrust <http://www.weboftrust.info> that I hosted last fall. One of the broad requests from the last event was that we needed better understanding of the use cases and problems from a broader perspective than the mostly western developers. I am by doing the follow-on design workshop after the UN event will help is get more participation from engineers from the "Majority World".
